Among the Roman cities beyond the Euphrates, we distinguissi two recent foundations, which were named from Theodosius, and the relies of the martyrs; and two capitals‚ Amida and Edessa, which are celebrated in the history of every age. Their strength was proportioned by Justinian to the dan- ger of their situation. A ditch and palisade might be sufficient to resist the artless force of the cavalry of Scythia3 but more elaborate works were required to sustain a regular siege against the arms and treasures of the great king. His skilful engineers understood the methods of condueting deep mines, and of raising platforms to the level of the rampart: he shook the strongest battlements with his military engines, and sometimes advanced to the affault with abline of moveable turrets on the backs of elephants.
